thread.title: Storm hits CT tonight with some snow before heavy rain and possible flash flooding, NWS says
thread.title_full: Storm hits CT tonight with some snow before heavy rain and possible flash flooding, NWS says

author: Peter Yankowski, Staff writer
title: Storm hits CT tonight with some snow before heavy rain and possible flash flooding, NWS says
text:
After a sunny and chilly Friday in Connecticut, Saturday
will bring heavy rain, a mix of snow in parts of the state and a potential for flooding, the National Weather Service said.
The inclement weather will start late Friday night, bringing a wintry mix of rain and snow to northern parts of the state that could result in slippery roads Saturday morning.
The weather service has issued flood watches across all of Connecticut. The watches are in effect from early Saturday until early Sunday.
Southern parts of Connecticut are expected to see more than 2.5 inches of rain.
"Rain develops Friday night after midnight, with a six to eight-hour period of moderate to heavy rain expected late Saturday morning into the afternoon," the
weather service said. "This will likely lead to scattered to widespread minor urban and poor drainage flooding with a localized flash flood threat during this time."
The agency said the rain is expected to taper off from west to east Saturday night, however, "there could be some lingering flooding, especially on some rivers and streams."
Northern Connecticut should see the precipitation start as either snow, or a mix of rain and sleet or snow tonight. That could lead to slippery roads on Saturday morning.
Winter weather advisories have been issued for Litchfield and Hartford counties from late Friday and into Saturday morning.
"Precipitation will initially spread from west to east as snow, before transitioning to a wintry mix of rain, freezing rain, sleet, and snow, and ultimately to all rain. Sheltered valleys may see a later transition to rain and higher accumulations of ice and snow,"
the weather service said.
The agency said drivers should "plan on slippery road conditions."
While northern portions of Massachusetts could see over an inch of snow, northern Connecticut is expected to get less than a quarter-inch.
Ahead of the storm, Friday should be dry and see a mix of sun and increasing clouds. Highs will be in the upper 30s to low 40s. Wind will make it feel much colder, with wind chill values in the teens in some places.
Saturday should see highs in the low 50s during the rain event.
After the rain dries up, Sunday will end the weekend with mostly to partly sunny skies and highs in the 40s.
